cleaned_text: John Mayer John Mayer |Background information| |Birth name||John Clayton Mayer| |Born||October 16, Singer - songwriter - guitarist - Vocals - guitar - Villanova Junction - LoFi Masters [Dead & Company](/wiki/Dead_%26_Company) [johnmayer](http://johnmayer.com) .com John Clayton Mayer [[1]](#cite_note-allmusicbio-1) ( [/me.r/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English) [MAY-r](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key); born October 16, 1977) is an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist. [[2]](#cite_note-2) Born and raised in [Fairfield County, Connecticut](/wiki/Fairfield_County,_Connecticut), Mayer attended [Berklee College of Music](/wiki/Berklee_College_of_Music) in [Boston](/wiki/Boston), but left and moved to [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta) in 1997 with [Clay Cook](/wiki/Clay_Cook). Together, they formed a short-lived two-man band called Lo-Fi Masters. After their split, Mayer continued to play local clubs, refining his skills and gaining a following. After his appearance at the 2000 [South by Southwest](/wiki/South_by_Southwest) festival, he was signed to [Aware Records](/wiki/Aware_Records), and eventually to [Columbia Records](/wiki/Columbia_Records), which released his first [extended play](/wiki/Extended_play) [Inside His following (2001) and [Heavier Things](/wiki/Heavier_Things) (2003)—performed well commercially, achieving [multi-platinum](/wiki/Music_recording_certification) status. In 2003, he won the [Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Male_Pop_Vocal_Performance) for his single " [Your Body Is a Wonderland](/wiki/Your_Body_Is_a_Wonderland)". By 2005, Mayer had moved away from the acoustic music that characterized his early records, and begun performing the [blues](/wiki/Blues) and rock music that had originally influenced him as a musician. He collaborated with blues artists such as [B.B. King](/wiki/B.B._King), [Buddy Guy](/wiki/Buddy_Guy), and [Eric Clapton](/wiki/Eric_Clapton). Forming Trio](/wiki/John_Mayer_Trio), he released a live album, [Try!](/wiki/Try!), in 2005 and his third studio album [Continuum](/wiki/Continuum_(John_Mayer_album)) in 2006. Both albums received positive reviews, and Continuum earned Mayer a [2007](/wiki/49th_Annual_Grammy_Awards) [Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Pop_Vocal_Album). He also won [Best Male Pop Vocal Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Male_Pop_Vocal_Performance) for " [Waiting on the World to Change](/wiki/Waiting_on_the_World_to_Change)". That album was followed by [Battle Studies](/wiki/Battle_Studies_(album)) in 2009, a return to pop, with a Battle Studies World Tour. After having several controversial incidents with the media, Mayer withdrew from public life in 2010 and began work on his fifth studio album, [Born and Raised](/wiki/Born_and_Raised_(John_Mayer_album)), which drew inspiration from the 1970s pop music of [Laurel Canyon](/wiki/Laurel_Canyon,_Los_Angeles#History). However, the discovery of a [granuloma](/wiki/Granuloma) on his vocal cords delayed the release of the album until May 2012, and forced him to cancel the planned tour. The album received a generally favorable reception, though was less commercially successful than his previous work. Mayer began performing as a singer again in January 2013, and that year released his sixth studio album, [Paradise Valley](/wiki/Paradise_Valley_(album)), which incorporates [country music](/wiki/Country_music) influences. By 2014, he had sold a total of over 20 million albums worldwide. [[3]](#cite_note-3) His seventh album, [The Search for Everything](/wiki/The_Search_for_Everything), a loose concept album based around the theme of a romantic break-up, was released in 2017. Mayer released his latest album, [Sob Rock](/wiki/Sob_Rock), inspired by 1980s [soft rock](/wiki/Soft_rock) music, in July 2021. In 2015, three former members of the [Grateful Dead](/wiki/Grateful_Dead) joined with Mayer and two other musicians to form the band [Dead & Company](/wiki/Dead_%26_Company). [[4]](#cite_note-deadtour-4) It was the latest of several [reunions](/wiki/Reunions_of_the_Grateful_Dead) of the band's surviving members since [Jerry Garcia](/wiki/Jerry_Garcia)'s death in 1995. [[5]](#cite_note-NYT-Launch16-5) [[6]](#cite_note-Nev11.27.A-6) They continued to play shows until 2023. [[7]](#cite_note-7) Mayer's secondary career pursuits extend to television hosting, comedy, and writing; he has [authored columns](/wiki/Columnist) for magazines such as [Esquire](/wiki/Esquire_(magazine)). He supports various causes and has performed at charity benefits. He is a watch aficionado (with a collection he values in the "tens of millions" of dollars), contributing to the watch site [Hodinkee](/wiki/Hodinkee), and has been on the jury at the [Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Genève](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Prix_d%27Horlogerie_de_Gen%C3%A8ve). [[8]](#cite_note-wrist-8) Early life Mayer was born on October 16, 1977, in [Bridgeport, Connecticut](/wiki/Bridgeport,_Connecticut). [[1]](#cite_note-allmusicbio-1) His father, Richard Mayer (b. 1927), was a high-school principal, and his mother, Margaret (née Hoffman; b. 1947), was a middle-school English teacher. [[9]](#cite_note-eliscu-9) [[10]](#cite_note-hip-10) He grew up in nearby [Fairfield](/wiki/Fairfield,_Connecticut), the middle child between older half-sister Rachel, [[11]](#cite_note-11) older brother Carl, and younger brother Ben. [[12]](#cite_note-Brothers-12) [[13]](#cite_note-13) His father is [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish), and Mayer has said that he relates to [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism). [[14]](#cite_note-Playboy-14) As an elementary school student, Mayer became close friends with future tennis star [James Blake](/wiki/James_Blake_(tennis)), and they played Nintendo together weekday afternoons after school for three years. [[15]](#cite_note-15) He attended the [Center for Global Studies at Brien McMahon High School](/wiki/Center_for_Global_Studies_at_Brien_McMahon_High_School) in [Norwalk](/wiki/Norwalk,_Connecticut) for his junior year (then known as the Center for Japanese Studies Abroad, a [magnet program](/wiki/Magnet_school) for learning Japanese). [[9]](#cite_note-eliscu-9) After watching [Michael J. Fox](/wiki/Michael_J._Fox)'s guitar performance as [Marty McFly](/wiki/Marty_McFly) in [Back to the Future](/wiki/Back_to_the_Future), Mayer became fascinated with the instrument. [[16]](#cite_note-16) When he turned 13 years old, his father rented one for him. [[17]](#cite_note-17) [[18]](#cite_note-AskMen-18) A neighbor gave Mayer a [Stevie Ray Vaughan](/wiki/Stevie_Ray_Vaughan) cassette, which cultivated Mayer's love of blues music. [[19]](#cite_note-CU-19) [[a]](#cnote_a) According to Mayer, his fascination with Vaughan started a "genealogical hunt" that led him to started taking lessons from a local guitar shop owner, Al Ferrante, and soon became consumed. [[21]](#cite_note-Hedegaard-21) [[22]](#cite_note-Mather-22) His singular focus concerned his parents, and they twice took him to see a psychiatrist, who determined him to be healthy. [[21]](#cite_note-Hedegaard-21) [[22]](#cite_note-Mather-22) Mayer says that his parents' contentious marriage led him to "disappear and create my own world I could believe in". [[21]](#cite_note-Hedegaard-21) After two years of practice, he started playing at bars and other venues, while still in high school. [[18]](#cite_note-AskMen-18) In addition to performing solo, he was a member of a band called Villanova Junction (named for a [Jimi Hendrix](/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix) song) with Tim Procaccini, Joe Beleznay, and Rich Wolf. [[21]](#cite_note-Hedegaard-21) [[23]](#cite_note-TW-23) When Mayer was 17, he was stricken with [cardiac dysrhythmia](/wiki/Cardiac_dysrhythmia) and was hospitalized for a weekend. Reflecting on the incident, Mayer said, "That was the moment the songwriter in me was born", and he penned his first lyrics the night he left the hospital. [[24]](#cite_note-RS06-24) Shortly thereafter, he began suffering from [panic attacks](/wiki/Panic_attacks), and says he feared having to enter a [mental institution](/wiki/Mental_institution). [[21]](#cite_note-Hedegaard-21) He continues to manage such episodes with [anti-anxiety medication](/wiki/Anti-anxiety_drug). [[24]](#cite_note-RS06-24) [[25]](#cite_note-MandS-25) Career Early career (1996-1999) Mayer considered skipping college to pursue music, but his parents dissuaded him. [[21]](#cite_note-Hedegaard-21) He enrolled at the [Berklee College of Music](/wiki/Berklee_College_of_Music) in 1997 at age 19. [[26]](#cite_note-ELLE-26) At the urging of his college friend [Clay Cook](/wiki/Clay_Cook), they left Berklee after two semesters and moved to Atlanta; there, they formed a two-man band called LoFi Masters, and began performing in local coffee houses and club venues such as [Eddie's Attic](/wiki/Eddie%27s_Attic). [[27]](#cite_note-Berklee-27) [[18]](#cite_note-AskMen-18) According to Cook, they experienced musical differences due to Mayer's desire to move more towards pop music. [[28]](#cite_note-MOA-28) The two parted ways and Mayer embarked on a solo career. [[27]](#cite_note-Berklee-27) With the help of local producer and engineer Glenn Matullo, Mayer recorded the independent [EP](/wiki/Extended_play) [Inside Wants Out](/wiki/Inside_Wants_Out). The EP includes eight songs with Mayer on lead vocals and guitars. For the opening track, "Back To You", a full band was enlisted, including co-producer [David "DeLa" LaBruyere](/wiki/David_LaBruyere) on bass guitars. [[29]](#cite_note-MO-29) Cook had co-written many of the album's songs, including its first commercial single release, " [No Such Thing](/wiki/No_Such_Thing_(John_Mayer_song))"; however, his only performance contribution was backing vocals on the song "Comfortable". [[28]](#cite_note-MOA-28) Major label and commercial success (2000-2004) Mayer and LaBruyere performed throughout Georgia and nearby states. [[30]](#cite_note-Graham-30) Also, as his career coincided with the then-nascent internet music market, Mayer benefited from an online following. [[31]](#cite_note-hay-31) Mayer came to the attention of [Gregg Latterman](/wiki/Gregg_Latterman) at Aware Records through an acquaintance of Mayer's, a lawyer, who sent Aware his EP. [[32]](#cite_note-32) [[22]](#cite_note-Mather-22) [[33]](#cite_note-33) In early 2001, after including him in Aware Festival concerts and his songs on Aware compilations, Aware released Mayer's internet-only album, [Room for Squares](/wiki/Room_for_Squares). During this time, Aware concluded a deal with [Columbia Records](/wiki/Columbia_Records) that gave Columbia first pick in signing Aware artists. [[34]](#cite_note-34) In September, Columbia remixed and re-released Room for Squares. [[35]](#cite_note-malindanewman-35) As part of the major label "debut", the album's artwork was updated, and the track "3x5" was added. The re-release included reworked studio versions of the first four songs from Inside Wants Out. [[36]](#cite_note-36) By the end of 2002, Room for Squares had spawned several radio hits, including " [No Such Thing](/wiki/No_Such_Thing_(John_Mayer_song))", " [Your Body Is a Wonderland](/wiki/Your_Body_Is_a_Wonderland)", and " [Why Georgia](/wiki/Why_Georgia)". It also received general praise critically, and Mayer drew comparisons to [Dave Matthews](/wiki/Dave_Matthews). [[27]](#cite_note-Berklee-27) [[35]](#cite_note-malindanewman-35) In 2003, Mayer won a Grammy for [Best Male Pop Vocal Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Male_Pop_Vocal_Performance) for "Your Body Is a Wonderland". [[37]](#cite_note-Grammyverification-37) In his acceptance speech he remarked, "This is very, very fast, and I promise to catch up." [[22]](#cite_note-Mather-22) He also figuratively referred to himself as being 16, a remark that many mistook to mean that he was 16 years old at the time. [[38]](#cite_note-RSG07-38) In February 2003, Mayer released a live CD and DVD of a concert in [Birmingham, Alabama](/wiki/Birmingham,_Alabama) titled [Any Given Thursday](/wiki/Any_Given_Thursday), which included songs previously not recorded, such as "Man on the Side", " [Something's Missing](/wiki/Something%27s_Missing_(John_Mayer_song))", and "Covered in Rain". Commercially, the album peaked at number 17 on the Billboard 200 chart. [[39]](#cite_note-Amazon_-_Any_Given_Thursday-39) Its accompanying DVD release received conservative—although consistent—praise, with critics torn between his pop-idol image, and (at the time) emerging guitar prowess. [[40]](#cite_note-EW-40) Erik Crawford of [AllMusic](/wiki/AllMusic) asked, "Is [Mayer] the consummate guitar hero exemplified when he plays a cover of Stevie Ray Vaughan's ' [Lenny](/wiki/Lenny_(instrumental))', or is he the teen idol that the pubescent girls shriek for after he plays 'Your Body Is a Wonderland'?" [[41]](#cite_note-41) [[42]](#cite_note-42) That summer, Mayer went on the road with [Counting Crows](/wiki/Counting_Crows) in a tour that spanned 42 dates between July 7 and September 2. [[43]](#cite_note-43) [Heavier Things](/wiki/Heavier_Things), Mayer's second album, was released in 2003 to generally favorable reviews. Rolling Stone, Allmusic, and [Blender](/wiki/Blender_(magazine)) all gave positive, although reserved, feedback. [[44]](#cite_note-44) The album was commercially successful, and while it did not sell as well as Room for Squares, it peaked at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart. The song " [Daughters](/wiki/Daughters_(John_Mayer_song))" won the 2005 Grammy for [Song of the Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year), [[37]](#cite_note-Grammyverification-37) and reached #1 on the Billboard Adult Pop Songs chart [[45]](#cite_note-45) and #19 on the Billboard Hot 100. [[46]](#cite_note-46) He dedicated the award to his grandmother, Annie Hoffman, who had died in May 2004. [[47]](#cite_note-47) He also won Best Male Pop Vocal Performance. On February 9, 2009, Mayer told [Ellen DeGeneres](/wiki/Ellen_DeGeneres) that he thought he should not have won the Grammy for Song of the year because he thought that Alicia Keys' " [If I Ain't Got You](/wiki/If_I_Ain%27t_Got_You)" was the better song. Because of this, he removed the top half of the Grammy and gave it to Keys, and kept the bottom part for himself. At the 37th Annual [Songwriters Hall of Fame](/wiki/Songwriters_Hall_of_Fame) Induction Ceremony in 2006, Mayer received the [Hal David Starlight Award](/wiki/Hal_David_Starlight_Award). [[48]](#cite_note-48) Mayer again recorded live concerts across seven nights of his U.S. tour in 2004. These recordings were released to the [iTunes Store](/wiki/ITunes_Store) under the title [As/Is](/wiki/As/Is), indicating that the errors were included along with the good moments. A few months later, a "best of" CD was compiled from the As/Is nights. The album included a previously unreleased cover of [Marvin Gaye](/wiki/Marvin_Gaye)'s song " [Inner City Blues (Make Me Wanna Holler)](/wiki/Inner_City_Blues_(Make_Me_Wanna_Holler))", featuring a solo from Mayer's supporting act—jazz and blues turntablist [DJ Logic](/wiki/DJ_Logic). The album covers of the As/Is releases feature drawings of [anthropomorphic](/wiki/Anthropomorphic) bunnies. [[49]](#cite_note-49) Change in musical direction (2005-2008) As early as 2002, Chris Willman with Entertainment Weekly said that Mayer was "more historically savvy, and more ambitious than you'd guess from the unforced earnestness of [Room for] Squares". [[50]](#cite_note-willman-50) However, Mayer was largely associated with the Adult Contemporary and singer-songwriter genres. [[50]](#cite_note-willman-50) Fame allowed him access to his early influences, and he began collaborating with blues and jazz artists. He accompanied Buddy Guy in a concert at the Irving Plaza in December 2003. [[51]](#cite_note-51) He toured with jazz pianist [Herbie Hancock](/wiki/Herbie_Hancock), including a show at the [Bonnaroo Music Festival](/wiki/Bonnaroo_Music_Festival). [[52]](#cite_note-52) He also performed on Although Mayer maintained his reputation as a singer-songwriter, he gained distinction as a guitarist. Following the conclusion of his Heavier Things tour, Mayer began working with artists, including those from other genres of music. His voice was sampled on the song " [Go](/wiki/Be_(Common_album)#"Go!")" by rapper [Common](/wiki/Common_(rapper)), and he appeared on a hidden track called "Bittersweet Poetry" from the [Kanye West](/wiki/Kanye_West) album [Graduation](/wiki/Graduation_(album)). [[b]](#cnote_b) praise from rap heavyweights [Jay-Z](/wiki/Jay-Z) and [Nelly](/wiki/Nelly). [[53]](#cite_note-53) When asked about his presence in the [hip hop](/wiki/Hip_hop) community, Mayer said, "It's not music out there right now. That's why, to me, hip-hop is where rock used to be." [[54]](#cite_note-trio-54) Around this time Mayer announced that he was "closing up shop on acoustic sensitivity". [[54]](#cite_note-trio-54) In the spring of 2005, Mayer formed the John Mayer Trio with bassist [Pino Palladino](/wiki/Pino_Palladino) and drummer [Steve Jordan](/wiki/Steve_Jordan_(musician)), both of whom he had met through studio sessions. The trio combined blues and rock music. In October 2005, they opened for [the Rolling Stones](/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones) [[55]](#cite_note-55) and that November released a live album called [Try!](/wiki/Try!) The band took a break in mid-2006. Mayer's third studio album, titled [Continuum](/wiki/Continuum_(John_Mayer_album)), was released on September 12, 2006, produced by Mayer and [Steve Jordan](/wiki/Steve_Jordan_(musician)). Mayer suggested the album was intended to combine blues and pop. In that vein, two of the tracks from his Trio release Try!—"Vultures" and "Gravity"—were included on Continuum. [[26]](#cite_note-ELLE-26) Despite his excitement, in a Rolling Stone interview, Mayer recalled that after former Columbia Records head [Don Ienner](/wiki/Don_Ienner) panned Continuum he briefly considered quitting music and studying design full-time. [[24]](#cite_note-RS06-24) In May 2006, Mayer contributed a cover of the song " [Route 66](/wiki/(Get_Your_Kicks_on)_Route_66#Other_recorded_renditions)" for the [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar) animated film [Cars](/wiki/Cars_(film)) (2006). Mayer's rendition garnered a nomination at the [49th Grammy Awards](/wiki/49th_Grammy_Awards) for [Best Solo Rock Vocal Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Solo_Rock_Vocal_Performance). The first single from Continuum was " [Waiting on the World to Change](/wiki/Waiting_on_the_World_to_Change)", which debuted on [The Ron and Fez Show](/wiki/The_Ron_and_Fez_Show). The song was the third-most downloaded song of the week on the [iTunes Store](/wiki/ITunes_Store) following its release on July 11, 2006,[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] and debuted at Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100) Chart.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] On August 23, 2006, Mayer debuted the entire album on the Los Angeles radio station [Star 98.7](/wiki/KYSR), offering commentary on each track. [[56]](#cite_note-56) A subsequent version was released the next day on the [Clear Channel Music](/wiki/Clear_Channel_Communications) website as a streaming sneak preview. On September 21, 2006, Mayer appeared on [CSI: Crime Scene Investigation](/wiki/CSI:_Crime_Scene_Investigation) in the episode "Built to Kill, Part 1", playing "Waiting on the World to Change" and "Slow Dancing in a Burning Room". The song "Gravity" was featured on the television series [House](/wiki/House_(TV_series)), in the episode "Cane & Able" and [Numb3rs](/wiki/Numb3rs). He recorded a session for the British program [Live from Abbey Road](/wiki/Live_from_Abbey_Road) at [Abbey Road Studios](/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios) on October 22, 2006.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] On December 7, 2006, Mayer was nominated for five Grammy Awards, including [Album of the Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year). [[57]](#cite_note-57) The Trio received a nomination for Try!. He won two: Best Pop Song with Vocal for "Waiting on the World to Change" and [Best Pop Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Pop_Album) for Continuum. [[37]](#cite_note-Grammyverification-37) Mayer remixed an acoustic version of his single "Waiting on the World to Change" with vocal additions from fellow musician [Ben Harper](/wiki/Ben_Harper). In preparation for Continuum, Mayer had booked the [Village Recorder](/wiki/Village_Recorder) in Los Angeles to record five acoustic versions of his songs with veteran musician [Robbie McIntosh](/wiki/Robbie_McIntosh). These recordings became [The Village Sessions](/wiki/The_Village_Sessions), an EP released on December 12, 2006. As usual, Mayer oversaw the artwork. [[58]](#cite_note-58) The initial North American Continuum tour ended on February 28, 2007, with a show at [Madison Square Garden](/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] On November 20, 2007, the re-issue of Continuum became available online and in stores. The release contained a bonus disc of six live songs from his 2007 tour: five from Continuum and a cover of the [Ray Charles](/wiki/Ray_Charles) song " [I Don't Need No Doctor](/wiki/I_Don%27t_Need_No_Doctor)". [[59]](#cite_note-59) His single " [Say](/wiki/Say_(John_Mayer_song))", from the film The Bucket List, became available through [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes).[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] On December 6, 2007, "Belief" was nominated for Best Male Pop Vocal for the [50th Annual Grammy Awards](/wiki/50th_Annual_Grammy_Awards). He accompanied [Alicia Keys](/wiki/Alicia_Keys) on guitar on her song " [No One](/wiki/No_One_(Alicia_Keys_song))" at the ceremony. [[60]](#cite_note-60) Additionally, he was selected by the editors of Time magazine as one of the [100 Most Influential People of 2007](/wiki/Time_100), listed among artists and entertainers. [[61]](#cite_note-time100-61) In February 2008, Mayer hosted a three-day Caribbean cruise event that included performances with various musicians including [David Ryan Harris](/wiki/David_Ryan_Harris), [Brett Dennen](/wiki/Brett_Dennen), [Colbie Caillat](/wiki/Colbie_Caillat), was called "The Mayercraft Carrier" and was held aboard the cruise ship known as the [Carnival Victory](/wiki/Carnival_Victory). [[62]](#cite_note-62) A follow-up cruise titled "Mayercraft Carrier 2" sailed from Los Angeles March 27-31, 2009, on the [Carnival Splendor](/wiki/Carnival_Splendor). [[63]](#cite_note-63) On July 1, 2008, Mayer released [Where the Light Is](/wiki/Where_the_Light_Is:_John_Mayer_Live_in_Los_Angeles), a live concert film of Mayer's performance at the Nokia Theatre [L.A. Live](/wiki/L.A._Live) on December 8, 2007. [[64]](#cite_note-RS_where_the_light_is-64) The film was directed by [Danny Clinch](/wiki/Danny_Clinch). [[65]](#cite_note-65) It features Mayer opening with an acoustic set, followed by a blues set with the Trio and concluded by a full set with the band from the Continuum album. [[66]](#cite_note-billboard_blackberry-66) Battle Studies (2009) Australian artist [Guy Sebastian](/wiki/Guy_Sebastian) invited Mayer to collaborate on three songs from his 2009 album [Like It Like That](/wiki/Like_It_Like_That_(album)). [[67]](#cite_note-67) Mayer also played guitar on the title track of [Crosby Loggins](/wiki/Crosby_Loggins)' debut LP, Time to Move. [[68]](#cite_note-68) On July 7, 2009, Mayer performed an instrumental guitar version of [Michael Jackson](/wiki/Michael_Jackson)'s " second [Here We Go Again](/wiki/Here_We_Go_Again_(Demi_Lovato_album)), released later that month. [[70]](#cite_note-70) After the overwhelming success of Continuum, Mayer confessed to be intimidated with beginning on a follow-up. However, he stated, "I think it got a lot easier when I realized that no matter what I do, it's not going to be Continuum, good or bad." [[71]](#cite_note-micktaylor-71) On November 17, 2009, Mayer's fourth studio album, [Battle Studies](/wiki/Battle_Studies_(album)), debuted at number one on the U.S. [Billboard 200](/wiki/Billboard_200) album chart. [[72]](#cite_note-72) The first single, " [Who Says](/wiki/Who_Says_(John_Mayer_song))", was released on September 24, 2009, in advance of the album, followed on October 19 by " [Heartbreak Warfare](/wiki/Heartbreak_Warfare)" and " [Half of My Heart](/wiki/Half_of_My_Heart)" on June 21, 2010. The accompanying arena tour grossed US$45 million. [[73]](#cite_note-DIEHL-73) Despite the album's commercial success, critics reactions were mixed. Some reviews glowed, calling it his "most adventurous", [[74]](#cite_note-74) [[75]](#cite_note-75) others called the album "safe" and noted that "Mayer the singer-songwriter and Mayer the man about town sometimes seem disconnected, like they don't even belong in the same body". [[21]](#cite_note-Hedegaard-21) [[76]](#cite_note-76) [[77]](#cite_note-77) [[78]](#cite_note-78) Mayer admitted to Rolling Stone that he thought Battle Studies was not his best album. [[79]](#cite_note-79) [[80]](#cite_note-80) Personal troubles and hiatus (2010-2013) I did a lot of therapy, like anti-acid reflux, and it didn't work, then I went on vocal rest. No alcohol. No spicy food. No talking. Most of September I wasn't talking at all. I'd have a Bluetooth keyboard, and someone would have an iPad to read what I type. I had to point to menus at restaurants. John Mayer [[81]](#cite_note-mayer_silent-81) Following two revealing and highly controversial magazine interviews in February 2010 with Rolling Stone and Playboy magazines, [[82]](#cite_note-outrage-82) Mayer withdrew from public life and ceased giving interviews. While still on tour for Battle Studies, he began work in earnest on his fifth studio album—which drew on the popular music of [Laurel Canyon](/wiki/Laurel_Canyon,_Los_Angeles#History) in the early 1970s. [[83]](#cite_note-sniping-83) Around this time, he began to experience vocal problems, and sought medical assistance. [[73]](#cite_note-DIEHL-73) On September 16, 2011, he posted on his blog that his next record, Born and Raised, would be delayed due to treatment he was receiving for a [granuloma](/wiki/Granuloma) discovered on his vocal cords. [[84]](#cite_note-84) Mayer described the event as a "temporary setback" and added that the album was entirely finished except for a few vocal tracks. [[85]](#cite_note-85) A month later, on October 20, 2011, Mayer posted, "I had surgery this afternoon to remove it and am now on complete vocal rest for a month or more," during which he planned to "travel the country, look, and listen". [[86]](#cite_note-86) However, the surgery did not work as expected, and he had to undergo another one that August. [[81]](#cite_note-mayer_silent-81) [[87]](#cite_note-patrickdoyle-87) During his travels, he visited and fell in love with [Bozeman, Montana](/wiki/Bozeman,_Montana), where he bought a house and re-settled in the spring of 2012. [[88]](#cite_note-ellen-88) [[89]](#cite_note-Missoula_Independent-89) [[90]](#cite_note-CBS_Sunday_morning-90) With his treatments complete, Mayer finished the vocals on Born and Raised, [[73]](#cite_note-DIEHL-73) and the album's first single, "Shadow Days", was released on February 27, 2012. The following day, he released the track listing for the album, announcing that it would be released on May 22 of that year.
